Issues.Title: [Question] Referencing .NET Framework WinForms from .NET Core WinForms
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

8.0.1

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Not tested/verified

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

_No response_

### Issue description

How is WinForms NET Core -> NET Framework intended to work?
I noticed that when I create old csproj style WinForms, Visual Studio does not report any warnings
When I switch to new csproj and change target framework moniker to .NET Framework 4.8, I start receiving warning which afaik cannot be disabled.
Using new csproj structure allows me to use Sync Namespaces feature in Visual Studio which is very important in large projects.
```

Severity	Code	Description	Project	File	Line	Suppression State
Warning	NU1702	ProjectReference 'C:\Users\Jan\Desktop\prace\WinFormsCsProjNewOldTest\WinFormsNetFrameworkClassLibraryNewProjectStructure\WinFormsNetFrameworkClassLibraryNewProjectStructure.csproj' was resolved using '.NETFramework,Version=v4.8' instead of the project target framework '.NETCoreApp,Version=v8.0'. This project may not be fully compatible with your project.	WinFormsNetCore	C:\Program Files\Microsoft Visual Studio\2022\Community\MSBuild\Current\Bin\amd64\Microsoft.Common.CurrentVersion.targets	1860	
```

Why is that? Is it supposed to be there?

![obrazek](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/64279914/2a857493-dd21-4784-94ee-d4c55e97a948)


### Steps to reproduce

https://github.com/janseris/WinFormsCsProjNewOldTest
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Question] Referencing .NET Framework WinForms from .NET Core WinForms" (#10438)

Issues.Title: Ensure that all WinForms controls ahve unit tests coverage
Issues.Body:
- [ ]  Investigate if we can re-enable code coverage on internal builds
        We enabled it in #514, however Coverage option is disabled in the build pipeline -  https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/95e83ed6e86c93c10020a7c92a6c9d459f65f6a5/eng/pipelines/build.yml#L33.
- [ ] Generate list of controls with missing test coverage for public methods
- [ ] Work with @Olina-Zhang's team on adding the missing scenarios
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Ensure that all WinForms controls ahve unit tests coverage" (#10453)

Issues.Title: The WinformsControlTest application under the Winforms repository has the wrong button anchor property setting in the drag and drop form.
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.NET 9.0.100-alpha.1.23606.1

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Not tested/verified

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

No, reproduce in previous .Net versions

### Issue description

In the E2E test, the button in the lower right corner of the drag and drop form in the WinformsControlTest application under the Winforms repository disappears when the form is resized.

https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/104609169/70f02b24-1bf8-4131-b487-abcdb7b2f479



### Steps to reproduce

1. Git clone  https://github.com/dotnet/winforms
2. Open CMD from clone folder and run "start-vs.cmd" command open project
3. Select WinformsControlTest app, right click it to set as startup project
4. Build and run, click "drag and drop" button and resize form.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "The WinformsControlTest application under the Winforms repository has the wrong button anchor property setting in the drag and drop form." (#10449)

Issues.Title: Reduce nesting in LinkLabel
Issues.Body:
This is an example of how nesting can be reduced. Basic techniques:

- Inverting if blocks
- Adding early outs
- Moving larger blocks into nested functions

I updated a few additional types. Additionally:

- Override Dispose(bool) on LinkLabel to ensure we release the GDI+ resources
- Remove the null-forgiving operator from LinkLabel (without a major refactor)

###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://portal.fabricbot.ms/api/codeflow?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/10448)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Reduce nesting in LinkLabel" (#10448)

Issues.Title: ErrorProvider HasErrors returns incorrect value after clearing an error
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

7.0

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Not tested/verified

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

_No response_

### Issue description

The implementation of #5912 does not take into account clearing an individual error. The documentation for ErrorProvider.SetError states for the value "The error description string, or null or Empty to remove the error."

So HasErrors returns an incorrect value if SetError has ever been used, even if there is now no error.

### Steps to reproduce

Basic application logic is
  SetError(control, "Some error");
  _HasErrors should be true at this point_
  SetError(control, null);
  _HasErrors should be **false** at this point_
  
Given that GetError also creates an entry in _items with a null error the following will also cause incorrect results:
  _ = GetError(control);
  _HasErrors should be **false** at this point_
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "ErrorProvider HasErrors returns incorrect value after clearing an error" (#10424)

Issues.Title: Fix `ErrorProvider.HasErrors` so maintains correct value
Issues.Body:
Fixes #10424

###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://portal.fabricbot.ms/api/codeflow?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/10440)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Fix `ErrorProvider.HasErrors` so maintains correct value" (#10440)

Issues.Title: Add coding style documentation
Issues.Body:
Add a more detailed document on our team coding style.

To demonstrate code to the style standard I've updated the code in the Buttons subfolder. Also updated a few files from Primitives. Informational messages in the updated files are now greatly reduced.

Some of the things done:

- Fix spelling
- Use ternary operators
- Use target-typed new
- Fix some internal parameter names
- Use expression bodies
- Use pattern matching
- Add argument names for bools and nulls
- Remove regions

Thread static naming and shipped public API naming issues aren't easily addressable without suppressions. Added a global suppression file to suppress these particular issues to make the code less difficult to read. We shouldn't put other types of suppressions in this file.

Note that for some reason RadioButton.PerformAutoUpdates was getting the TypeDescriptor to clear sibling RadioButtons. I've set the property directly as this is significantly more performant and friendly to trimming.

PaddingConverter was unnecessarily complicated in creating it's strings. `int` to string never is impacted by culture.

###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://portal.fabricbot.ms/api/codeflow?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/10441)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Add coding style documentation" (#10441)

Issues.Title: The smart tag icon in the DemoConsole application becomes very large
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.Net 9.0: Main branch of Winforms repo

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Yes

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

Yes, this is a regression issue.

### Issue description

In [DemoConsole](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/tree/main/src/System.Windows.Forms/tests/IntegrationTests/DesignSurface/DemoConsole) test app of Winforms repo, Smart tag icons getting very large.

![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/86937911/dfdb07ad-a73b-4117-8948-cd7f2dabc929)

https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/86937911/59da3f2e-a1df-4d4b-bb9d-39cb5ac38c6d




### Steps to reproduce

Test sample: [DemoConsole](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/tree/main/src/System.Windows.Forms/tests/IntegrationTests/DesignSurface/DemoConsole) in Winforms repo
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "The smart tag icon in the DemoConsole application becomes very large" (#10444)

Issues.Title: DataGridView and its elements accessible objects are leaking in memory
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.NET 9.0.100-alpha.1.23606.1 + private dlls(build from main branch of WinForms repo)

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Not tested/verified

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

Yes, this issue cannot repro in .NET 9.0.100-alpha.1.23606.1, it may be caused by PR: [10407](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/10407).

### Issue description

The original issue is [7347](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/issues/7347).
DataGridView and its elements accessible objects are left in memory after the DataGridView control instance with its rows was inspected with accessibility tool (like Accessibility Insights/Inspect/Narrtor) and the form with DataGridView is closed, garbage is collected, but accessibility tool is still opened. 

Report from WinDbg:
![datagridview-memory leak](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/94418985/f8b3804d-b339-4dde-aff2-a36bba165a3f)


### Steps to reproduce

Tested sample application:
[DataGridView Sample.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/13595985/DataGridView.Sample.zip)

1.Create a parent form with two buttons: one will be opening a child form with the DataGridView control and the other will collect the garbage.
2. Start project without debugging(Ctrl+F5).
3. Attaching project to WinDbg and adding symbols folder.
4. Start the Accessibility Insights tool.
5. Press the second button to open the child form with DatGridView.
6. Automatic checks for the DataGridView control using Accessibility Insight.
7. Close the child form.
8. Clear memory with the first button of the parent form.
9. Don't close the Accessibility Insights tool.
10. Look for DataGridView accessible objects left in memory (using WinDbg).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "DataGridView and its elements accessible objects are leaking in memory" (#10443)

Issues.Body: Check and add missing test coverage for all controls

Issues.Title: Clean up DpiHelper
Issues.Body:
This change cleans up the DpiHelper by clarifying terminology, making behavior more consistent, and fixing a number of issues.

- Rename DpiHelper to ScaleHelper
- Use OS terms
- Use more descriptive naming
- Make scaling actions a no-op if scaling to 100% and just call ScaleHelper by default
- Encapsulate logical default values to avoid accidental unscaled use
- Keep parking window tracking within Application
- Remove System.Window.Forms dependency on SystemEvents
- Remove unreachable code from VsPropertyGrid
- Fixes the Application default font scaling.
- Update some comments (MonthCalendar comments were still in Java)

Most controls that scale use the initial System DPI and don't do any further scaling.

The idea here is that being explicit about what we're scaling to makes things clearer. Always using the ScaleHelper, reducing the caching of scaled values, and factoring the scaling together will make understanding the current behavior easier and make implementing dynamic scaling easier.

DockEditor.DockUI is an example where understanding class state is significantly easier.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Clean up DpiHelper" (#10434)

Issues.Title: Replace ArrayList with List in several designers
Issues.Body:
Contributes to #8140


## Proposed changes

- Replace `ArrayList` with `List<IComponent>` in `ControlDesigner`
- Replace `ArrayList` with `List<Control>` in `FlowLayoutPanelDesigner`
- ~~Replace `ArrayList` with `List<SnapLine>` in `FlowPanelDesigner`~~ see https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/10432#issuecomment-1841717995
- Replace `ArrayList` with `List<IComponent>` in `TabControlDesigner`

Issues.Title: [Accessibility] Narrator can't announce the new added row correctly for DataGrridView control
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

9.0.0-alpha.1.23576.1

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

Yes, Narrator can announce the new added row correctly for DataGrridView control in 8.0/7.0
For the 9.0, have the new change was introduced by PR: #10243 which caused this issue.

### Issue description

Narrator can't announce the new added row correctly for DataGrridView control in 9.0

### Steps to reproduce

**Reproduce steps:**
1. Create .NET Core winforms project targeting 9.0.
2. Add DataGridView control to the Form1.cs[Design] with some columns.
3. Build and run the project.
4. Launch the Narrator tool, and focus on first row.
5. Input some text on the textbox cell.
6. Press the Down keyboard to move the new added row.
7. Observe the results.

**Actual Results:**
After steps #5, the Narrator announce "Row 2 is added"
After steps #6, the Narrator announce  "Row 3, Column1 Row 3, Not sorted......."
![ActualBehaviour](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/38325459/44fabe28-386e-4809-9460-2604417cee52)
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/38325459/1878fcf6-743f-40e1-a949-a84ec349a42a)

**Expected Results:**
After steps #5, the Narrator announce the new added row correctly
![80Behaviour](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/38325459/6210ea42-57b4-4855-8e38-ec790bd48699)
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/38325459/efeee649-8c9b-4513-b84b-639e1bfbdbc7)

**More info:**
After steps #6. continue input some text on the new added new row, the Narrator always announce that" **Row 1, Editing Control, edit, <say-as interpret-as="spell">t</say-as>, Row Header Row 1, Row** <say-as interpret-as="cardinal">1</say-as> of <say-as interpret-as="cardinal">4</say-as> "
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/38325459/eefd21a1-7ed6-40ce-8347-792e80fc750f)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[Accessibility] Narrator can't announce the new added row correctly for DataGrridView control" (#10428)

Issues.Title: Exception in PropertyGrid when it run in RemoteDesignerHost
Issues.Body: ### Environment Microsoft Visual Studio Professional 2022 (64-bit) 17.8.2 ### .NET version .net 6+ ### Did this work in a previous version of Visual Studio and/or previous .NET release? _No response_ ### Issue description Hello. I’m from DevExpress. We have a problem with PropertyGrid when it run in RemoteDesignerHost: Our research led to the PropertyDescriptorGridEntry class. In the NotifyParentChange method we found a difference in the code for .net 6 and .net framework versions. In .net framework this code look like this I attach an example. In this example in .net version I wrote comment in ComponentChangeService class where an exception occurs in RemoteDesignerHost class ### Steps to reproduce 1. Download and unzip [Pivot_Error.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/13556605/Pivot_Error.zip) 2. Build and run WinFomNetExample project ### Diagnostics _No response_
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Exception in PropertyGrid when it run in RemoteDesignerHost" (#10427)

Issues.Title: System.ComponentModel.Design.Serialization.SerializationStore.Save(Stream stream) can not suppport .NET8
Issues.Body:
### Environment

OS: Microsoft Windows Version 22H2 (OS Build 19045.3570)
VisualStudio 2022: Version 17.8.2


### .NET version

.NET SDK:Version 8.0.100
Arch: X64(also can reproduce in other Arch)

### Did this work in a previous version of Visual Studio and/or previous .NET release?

The serialization works well in .NET Framework 4.8
A sample project is provided.

### Issue description

System.ComponentModel.Design.Serialization.SerializationStore.Save(Stream stream); 

> https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.componentmodel.design.serialization.serializationstore?view=net-7.0

The serialization works well in .NET Framework 4.8, but it shows 'platform not support' exception after we update to .NET8 SDK.

### Steps to reproduce

Call System.ComponentModel.Design.Serialization.SerializationStore.Save(Stream stream) function directly  to save a user control in .NET8
[WinFormsNET8.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/13553852/WinFormsNET8.zip)

![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/39147380/57416b82-0edb-409d-bdb3-e80110c5f75b)

![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/39147380/b8291438-c30c-4a1a-b112-93b20e75b349)


### Diagnostics

```text
We notice that, this function is support in .NET8 according to MSDN, but it throw 'platform not support' exception' when we call it.

> https://learn.microsoft.com/zh-cn/dotnet/api/system.componentmodel.design.serialization.serializationstore?view=net-8.0
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "System.ComponentModel.Design.Serialization.SerializationStore.Save(Stream stream) can not suppport .NET8" (#10425)
